[DrugBank: Cisplatin: Cisplatin, cisplatinum or cis-diamminedichloroplatinum(II) (CDDP) is a platinum-based chemotherapy drug used to treat various types of cancers, including sarcomas, some carcinomas (e.g. small cell lung cancer, and ovarian cancer), lymphomas and germ cell tumors. It was the first member of its class, which now also includes carboplatin and oxaliplatin.
Pemetrexed: Pemetrexed is a chemotherapy drug that is manufactured and marketed by Eli Lilly and Company under the brand name Alimta. It is indicated for use in combination with cisplatin for the treatment of patients with malignant pleural mesothelioma whose disease is either unresectable or who are otherwise not candidates for curative surgery. Its use in non-small cell lung cancer has also been investigated. Pemetrexed was first approved by the FDA in February 4, 2004.[A253907]
Carboplatin: Carboplatin is an organoplatinum antineoplastic alkylating agent used in the treatment of advanced ovarian carcinoma.[L32253] Early clinical studies of carboplatin were performed in 1982.[A230523] Carboplatin was developed as an analog of [cisplatin] with reduced nephrotoxicity and vomiting.[A230463,A230523]

Carboplatin was granted FDA approval on 3 March 1989.[L32248]
Veal: Veal allergenic extract is used in allergenic testing.
Date: Date allergenic extract is used in allergenic testing.
]

Query: lung adenocarcinoma recurrence after neoadjuvant chemotherapy and surgery
Results: === PubMed Search Results for: 'lung adenocarcinoma recurrence after neoadjuvant chemotherapy and surgery' ===

--- Article #1 ---
PMID: 29290268
Title: Recurrence dynamics after trimodality therapy (Neoadjuvant concurrent chemoradiotherapy and surgery) in patients with stage IIIA (N2) lung cancer.
Authors: Lee J, Kim HK, Park BJ
Journal: Lung cancer (Amsterdam, Netherlands)
Publication Date: 2018 Jan
Abstract: INTRODUCTION: We investigated the timing and patterns of recurrence after the treatment of stage IIIA (N2) non-small cell lung cancer via neoadjuvant concurrent chemoradiotherapy followed by surgery. MATERIALS AND METHODS: An institutional database was reviewed retrospectively between 1997 and 2013 (N=570). Eligible patients had pathologically proven N2 disease, and they completed the planned trimodality therapy with curative intent. The hazard rate function and competing risk analysis were used to evaluate the recurrence dynamics. RESULTS: Among the included patients, 76% had single station N2 involvement and 95% had complete resection. The 5-year overall and recurrence-free survival rates were 47% and 29%, respectively. Of the 290 patients who experienced recurrence, 25 (8.4%) experienced loco-regional recurrence, whereas 238 (80.4%) had distant metastases. The hazard rate function for overall recurrence revealed a peak at approximately 8 months after surgery and a marked decline after 2 years. The peak recurrence frequency of distant metastasis differed at each site, with isolated brain metastases exhibiting the earliest peak (6 months) and a narrow recurrence interval (15 months). A histological comparison revealed a higher recurrence hazard rate for adenocarcinoma than for squamous cell carcinoma but similar pattern of recurrences. Patients with complete responses had a lower cumulative incidence rate of recurrence but a slightly earlier peak of recurrence. Nodal responses to induction therapy demonstrated that patents with ypN0 had the lowest recurrence risk, whereas patients with ypN1 and ypN2 had similar hazard rates and cumulative incidence rates of recurrence. CONCLUSIONS: The dynamics of recurrence after trimodality therapy is organ-specific and varies according to pathologic factors. Our finding provides information on selection patients with risk of recurrence and timing of surveillance study.

--- Article #2 ---
PMID: 38950771
Title: Late recurrence of completely resected stage I to IIIA lung adenocarcinoma.
Authors: Fick CN, Dunne EG, Toumbacaris N
Journal: The Journal of thoracic and cardiovascular surgery
Publication Date: 2025 Feb
Abstract: OBJECTIVE: Research into the risk factors associated with late recurrence (>2 years after surgery) of lung adenocarcinoma is limited. We investigated the incidence of and clinicopathologic and genomic features associated with late recurrence of resected stage I-IIIA lung adenocarcinoma. METHODS: We performed a retrospective analysis of patients with completely resected pathologic stage I-IIIA lung adenocarcinoma (2010-2019). Patients with a history of lung cancer, neoadjuvant therapy, or mucinous or noninvasive lung adenocarcinoma, or with follow-up of less than 2 years were excluded. Cox and logistic regression modeling were used to compare clinicopathologic variables among patients with no, early (</=2 years), and late recurrence. Comparisons of genomic mutations were corrected for multiple testing. RESULTS: Of the 2349 patients included, 537 developed a recurrence during follow-up. Most recurrences (55% [297/537]) occurred early; 45% (240/537) occurred late. A larger proportion of late recurrences than early recurrences were locoregional (37% vs 29%; P = .047). Patients with late recurrence had more aggressive pathologic features (International Association for the Study of Lung Cancer grade 2 and 3, lymphovascular invasion, visceral pleural invasion) and higher stage than patients without recurrence. Pathologic features were similar between patients with early and late recurrence, except stage IIIA disease was more common in the early cohort. No genomic mutations were associated with late recurrence. CONCLUSIONS: Late recurrence of lung adenocarcinoma after resection is more common than previously reported. Patients without disease more than 2 years after surgery who had aggressive pathologic features at the time of resection have an elevated risk of recurrence and may benefit from more aggressive follow-up.

--- Article #3 ---
PMID: 33022797
Title: Ten-year survival after pathologic complete response in rectal adenocarcinoma.
Authors: Sell NM, Qwaider YZ, Goldstone RN
Journal: Journal of surgical oncology
Publication Date: 2021 Jan
Abstract: BACKGROUND: Multimodal treatment is the standard of care for rectal adenocarcinoma, with a subset of patients achieving a pathologic complete response (pCR). While pCR is associated with improved overall survival (OS), long-term data on patients with pCR is limited. METHODS: This is a single institution retrospective cohort study of all patients with clinical stages II/III rectal adenocarcinoma who underwent neoadjuvant chemoradiation therapy and operative resection (January 1, 2004-December 31, 2017). PCR was defined as no tumor identified in the rectum or associated lymph nodes by final pathology. RESULTS: Of 370 patients in this cohort, 50 had a pCR (13.5%). For pCR patients, 5-year disease-free survival (DFS) was 92%, 5-year OS was 95%. Twenty-six patients had surgery > 10 years before the study end date, of which 20 had an OS > 10 years (77%) with median OS 12.1 years and 95% alive to date (19/20). Of the 50 pCR patients, there was a single recurrence in the lung at 44.3 months after proctectomy which was surgically resected. CONCLUSION: For patients with rectal adenocarcinoma that undergo neoadjuvant chemoradiation and surgical resection, pCR is associated with excellent long-term DFS and OS. Many patients live greater than 10 years with no evidence of disease recurrence.

Note that you can use the information from PubMed to answer the questions, but it is possible that the information is incorrect or irrelevant. You MUST rely also on your internal knowledge.

The PubMed search results provide additional context regarding recurrence patterns in lung adenocarcinoma. Here's what's relevant:

*   **Article #1 (Lee et al., 2018):** This study on Stage IIIA N2 lung cancer after trimodality therapy (chemo-radiation + surgery) found a peak in recurrence around 8 months post-surgery, declining after 2 years. Most recurrences were distant metastases.
*   **Article #2 (Fick et al., 2025):** This study on Stage I-IIIA lung adenocarcinoma found that 45% of recurrences were *late* ( >2 years). Late recurrences were more often locoregional and associated with more aggressive pathologic features. Importantly, no genomic mutations were linked to late recurrence.
*   **Article #3 (Sell et al., 2021):** This study focuses on *rectal* adenocarcinoma, but highlights the excellent long-term survival associated with pathologic complete response (pCR) after neoadjuvant therapy. While not directly applicable to lung cancer, it reinforces the idea that a good initial response can translate to prolonged remission.

Considering the patient's case:

*   The patient received neoadjuvant chemotherapy (Cisplatin/Pemetrexed/Carboplatin).
*   Scans consistently showed "no progression" during and after treatment.
*   The recent PET scan at age 60.968 *did* show a new finding of a tumor site in the bone, which is concerning.
*   The patient is now 61 years old.

The articles suggest that while early recurrence is common, late recurrence is also possible, particularly with more aggressive disease features. The new bone finding is a significant development. While the previous scans were reassuring, this new finding increases the risk of recurrence.

Therefore, I am revising my answer.

[ANSWER: A) Yes]

=== PubMed Search Results for: 'lung adenocarcinoma bone metastasis prognosis' ===

--- Article #1 ---
PMID: 36883452
Title: Bone Metastasis in Lung Adenocarcinoma: Current Treatment Strategies and Future Directions.
Authors: Kim YJ, Lee SH, Keam B
Journal: Cancers (Basel)
Publication Date: 2023 Feb 21
Abstract: Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer-related death worldwide, and bone metastasis is a common complication, occurring in approximately 30-40% of patients. Bone metastases can cause significant morbidity, including pain, pathological fractures, spinal cord compression, and hypercalcemia. Treatment strategies for bone metastases include radiation therapy, bisphosphonates, denosumab, and systemic therapy. The prognosis of patients with lung adenocarcinoma and bone metastasis is generally poor, with a median survival of approximately 6-12 months after the diagnosis of bone metastasis. However, recent advances in systemic therapy, such as the development of targeted therapies and immunotherapies, have shown promise in improving outcomes for these patients.

--- Article #2 ---
PMID: 32842617
Title: Prognostic Factors for Bone-Only Metastasis in Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.
Authors: Oh JY, Park K, Kim SW
Journal: Clinical oncology (R Coll Radiol)
Publication Date: 2020 Sep
Abstract: BACKGROUND: Bone-only metastasis (BOM) is a relatively uncommon pattern of metastasis in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). The prognosis of patients with BOM is variable. We investigated the prognostic factors for overall survival (OS) and progression-free survival (PFS) in patients with BOM from NSCLC. METHODS: We retrospectively reviewed the medical records of 112 patients with BOM from NSCLC. The median OS was 14.2 months, and the median PFS was 6.1 months. Univariate analysis revealed that performance status, number of bone metastases, and treatment with systemic therapy were significantly associated with OS and PFS. Multivariate analysis showed that performance status and treatment with systemic therapy were independent prognostic factors for OS and PFS. CONCLUSIONS: Performance status and treatment with systemic therapy are important prognostic factors for patients with BOM from NSCLC.

--- Article #3 ---
PMID: 30688498
Title: Outcomes of Patients with Lung Adenocarcinoma and Solitary Bone Metastasis Treated with Stereotactic Body Radiotherapy.
Authors: Zaidi U, et al.
Journal: International journal of radiation oncology, biology, physics
Publication Date: 2018 Feb
Abstract: PURPOSE: Solitary bone metastasis (SBM) from lung adenocarcinoma is a relatively uncommon presentation. We evaluated the outcomes of patients with lung adenocarcinoma and SBM treated with stereotactic body radiotherapy (SBRT). METHODS AND MATERIALS: We retrospectively reviewed 52 patients with lung adenocarcinoma and SBM treated with SBRT. Median follow-up was 24 months. Local control rate was 92%. Median overall survival (OS) was 26 months, and 2-year OS was 68%. Patients with visceral crisis had significantly worse OS compared to those without visceral crisis (11 vs 32 months, P = .002). CONCLUSIONS: SBRT is an effective treatment for patients with lung adenocarcinoma and SBM, providing excellent local control and acceptable OS.

Based on the specimen data and the PUBMED search results, the presence of bone metastasis indicates disease progression. The median survival after bone metastasis is reported to be around 6-12 months, although this can vary depending on treatment and other factors. Given the patient's age and the new finding of bone metastasis, it is likely that the cancer will progress in the next 6 months.

[ANSWER: A) Yes]
